name: Energy production (kt of oil equivalent)
sourceNote: Energy production refers to forms of primary energy--petroleum (crude oil, natural gas liquids, and oil from nonconventional sources), natural gas, solid fuels (coal, lignite, and other derived fuels), and combustible renewables and waste--and primary electricity, all converted into oil equivalents.
sourceOrganization: International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

name: Access to electricity, rural (% of population)
sourceNote: Access to electricity, rural is the percentage of rural population with access to electricity.
sourceOrganization: World Bank, Sustainable Energy for all (SE4ALL) database from World Bank, Global Electrification database.

name: Access to electricity, urban (% of population)
sourceNote: Access to electricity, urban is the percentage of urban population with access to electricity.
sourceOrganization: World Bank, Sustainable Energy for All (SE4ALL) database from World Bank, Global Electrification database.

name: GDP per unit of energy use (PPP $ per kg of oil equivalent)
sourceNote: GDP per unit of energy use is the PPP GDP per kilogram of oil equivalent of energy use. PPP GDP is gross domestic product converted to current international dollars using purchasing power parity rates based on the 2011 ICP round. An international dollar has the same purchasing power over GDP as a U.S. dollar has in the United States.
sourceOrganization: International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp), and World Bank PPP data.

name: GDP per unit of energy use (constant 2011 PPP $ per kg of oil equivalent)
sourceNote: GDP per unit of energy use is the PPP GDP per kilogram of oil equivalent of energy use. PPP GDP is gross domestic product converted to 2011 constant international dollars using purchasing power parity rates. An international dollar has the same purchasing power over GDP as a U.S. dollar has in the United States.
sourceOrganization: International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp), and World Bank PPP data.

name: Energy imports, net (% of energy use)
sourceNote: Net energy imports are estimated as energy use less production, both measured in oil equivalents. A negative value indicates that the country is a net exporter. Energy use refers to use of primary energy before transformation to other end-use fuels, which is equal to indigenous production plus imports and stock changes, minus exports and fuels supplied to ships and aircraft engaged in international transport.
sourceOrganization: International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp) and United Nations, Energy Statistics Yearbook.

name: Access to non-solid fuel, rural (% of households)
sourceNote: Access to non-solid fuel, rural is the percentage of rural population with access to non-solid fuel.
sourceOrganization: World Bank, Sustainable Energy for all (SE4ALL) database from WHO Global Household Energy database.

name: Access to non-solid fuel, urban (% of households)
sourceNote: Access to non-solid fuel, urban is the percentage of urban population with access to non-solid fuel.
sourceOrganization: World Bank, Sustainable Energy for all (SE4ALL) database from WHO Global Household Energy database.

name: Access to non-solid fuel (% of households)
sourceNote: Access to non-solid fuel is the percentage of population with access to non-solid fuel.
sourceOrganization: World Bank, Sustainable Energy for all (SE4ALL) database from WHO Global Household Energy database.

name: Alternative and nuclear energy (% of total energy use)
sourceNote: Clean energy is noncarbohydrate energy that does not produce carbon dioxide when generated. It includes hydropower and nuclear, geothermal, and solar power, among others.
sourceOrganization: International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

name: Fossil fuel energy consumption (% of total)
sourceNote: Fossil fuel comprises coal, oil, petroleum, and natural gas products.
sourceOrganization: International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

name: Energy use (kg of oil equivalent) per $1,000 GDP (constant 2011 PPP)
sourceNote: Energy use per PPP GDP is the kilogram of oil equivalent of energy use per constant PPP GDP. Energy use refers to use of primary energy before transformation to other end-use fuels, which is equal to indigenous production plus imports and stock changes, minus exports and fuels supplied to ships and aircraft engaged in international transport. PPP GDP is gross domestic product converted to 2011 constant international dollars using purchasing power parity rates. An international dollar has the same purchasing power over GDP as a U.S. dollar has in the United States.
sourceOrganization: International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp), and World Bank PPP data.

name: Energy use (kt of oil equivalent)
sourceNote: Energy use refers to use of primary energy before transformation to other end-use fuels, which is equal to indigenous production plus imports and stock changes, minus exports and fuels supplied to ships and aircraft engaged in international transport.
sourceOrganization: International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

name: Combustible renewables and waste (metric tons of oil equivalent)
sourceNote: Combustible renewables and waste comprise solid biomass, liquid biomass, biogas, industrial waste, and municipal waste.
sourceOrganization: International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

name: Combustible renewables and waste (% of total energy)
sourceNote: Combustible renewables and waste comprise solid biomass, liquid biomass, biogas, industrial waste, and municipal waste, measured as a percentage of total energy use.
sourceOrganization: International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

name: Energy use (kg of oil equivalent per capita)
sourceNote: Energy use refers to use of primary energy before transformation to other end-use fuels, which is equal to indigenous production plus imports and stock changes, minus exports and fuels supplied to ships and aircraft engaged in international transport.
sourceOrganization: International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

name: Pump price for diesel fuel (US$ per liter)
sourceNote: Fuel prices refer to the pump prices of the most widely sold grade of diesel fuel. Prices have been converted from the local currency to U.S. dollars.

name: Pump price for gasoline (US$ per liter)
sourceNote: Fuel prices refer to the pump prices of the most widely sold grade of gasoline. Prices have been converted from the local currency to U.S. dollars.
